evidence.title: Teen Sleep Requirements
evidence.summary: Teenagers aged 13-18 need 8-10 hours of sleep per night for optimal health and development.

recommendation_templates.action: Aim for bedtime by {calculated_bedtime} to get {target_hours} hours of sleep.

evidence.title: Consistent Bedtime Benefits
evidence.summary: Maintaining a consistent sleep schedule, even on weekends, helps regulate the body's internal clock and improves sleep quality.

recommendation_templates.action: Try to go to bed and wake up at the same time each day, even on weekends.

evidence.title: Screen Time and Sleep Quality
evidence.summary: Blue light from screens can suppress melatonin production and delay sleep onset. Limiting screens 1 hour before bed improves sleep quality.

recommendation_templates.action: Put away phones and screens at least 1 hour before bedtime to help your body prepare for sleep.

evidence.title: Sleep and Growth Hormone
evidence.summary: Growth hormone is primarily released during deep sleep. Adequate sleep is essential for physical development during adolescence.

recommendation_templates.action: Prioritize getting 8-10 hours of sleep to support your growth and development goals.

evidence.title: Sleep and Athletic Performance
evidence.summary: Athletes who sleep less than 8 hours have 1.7x higher injury risk. Sleep improves reaction time, accuracy, and recovery.

recommendation_templates.action: Athletes need 8-10 hours of sleep for peak performance. Consider an earlier bedtime on training days.

evidence.title: Caloric Needs for Active Teens
evidence.summary: Active teen athletes may need 2,200-3,200 calories per day depending on age, sex, and activity level. Undereating can impair growth and performance.

recommendation_templates.action: Your body needs adequate fuel for training and growth. Consider adding nutritious snacks between meals.

evidence.title: Protein Needs for Active Teens
evidence.summary: Active teenagers need approximately 1.2-1.6g of protein per kg of body weight daily to support muscle growth and recovery.

recommendation_templates.action: Include protein at each meal. Good sources include chicken, fish, eggs, dairy, beans, and nuts.

evidence.title: Calcium for Bone Health
evidence.summary: Teens need approximately 1300mg of calcium per day to support bone development. This is especially important during growth spurts.

recommendation_templates.action: Aim for 3-4 servings of calcium-rich foods daily: milk, yogurt, cheese, fortified foods, or leafy greens.

evidence.title: Vitamin D Requirements
evidence.summary: Teens need approximately 600 IU of Vitamin D daily for calcium absorption and bone health. Sunlight and fortified foods are key sources.

recommendation_templates.action: Get some sunlight daily and include Vitamin D sources like fortified milk, fatty fish, or eggs.

evidence.title: Pre and Post Workout Nutrition
evidence.summary: Eating carbohydrates 1-2 hours before exercise and protein within 30 minutes after supports performance and recovery.

recommendation_templates.action: Have a carb-rich snack like a banana or toast 1-2 hours before your workout for energy.
Eat a snack with protein and carbs within 30 minutes after training to support recovery.

evidence.title: Hydration Guidelines
evidence.summary: Teen athletes should drink water before, during, and after exercise. A general guideline is 16-20 oz 2-3 hours before, and 7-10 oz every 10-20 minutes during activity.

recommendation_templates.action: Drink water throughout the day. Bring a water bottle to practice and take sips every 15-20 minutes.

evidence.title: Daily Activity Recommendation
evidence.summary: Children and adolescents should get at least 60 minutes of moderate-to-vigorous physical activity daily.

recommendation_templates.action: Aim for at least 60 minutes of physical activity each day. This can include sports, walking, or active play.

evidence.title: Youth Resistance Training Safety
evidence.summary: Resistance training is safe and beneficial for teens when properly supervised. Focus on technique over heavy weights, with 2-3 sessions per week.

recommendation_templates.action: Focus on learning proper form with lighter weights. Increase weight gradually as your technique improves.

evidence.title: Signs of Overtraining
evidence.summary: Overtraining can lead to fatigue, decreased performance, mood changes, and increased injury risk. Rest and recovery are essential parts of training.

recommendation_templates.action: Your body may need extra recovery time. Consider reducing intensity or taking an extra rest day this week.

evidence.title: Rest Day Importance
evidence.summary: Rest days allow muscles to repair and grow stronger. Teen athletes should have at least 1-2 rest days per week.

recommendation_templates.action: Schedule at least 1-2 rest days per week. Your muscles grow stronger during rest, not just during training.

evidence.title: Injury Prevention Through Warmup
evidence.summary: A proper warmup of 10-15 minutes increases blood flow, raises muscle temperature, and reduces injury risk by up to 50%.

recommendation_templates.action: Start with a 10-15 minute dynamic warmup including light jogging and movement-specific stretches.

evidence.title: Weight-Bearing Exercise Benefits
evidence.summary: Weight-bearing exercises like running, jumping, and sports stimulate bone growth and increase bone density during adolescence.

recommendation_templates.action: Include weight-bearing activities like running, basketball, or jumping exercises to strengthen your bones.

evidence.title: Bone Health Nutrition Triad
evidence.summary: Optimal bone health requires adequate calcium (1300mg), Vitamin D (600 IU), and protein intake combined with weight-bearing exercise.

recommendation_templates.action: Focus on the bone health triad: calcium-rich foods, Vitamin D exposure, and weight-bearing exercise.

evidence.title: Scoliosis-Specific Exercises
evidence.summary: Scoliosis-specific exercises (SSE) may help as an adjunctive treatment to slow curve progression in mild-to-moderate adolescent scoliosis.

recommendation_templates.action: Continue with your prescribed PT exercises regularly. Consistency is key for best results.

evidence.title: PT Adherence Importance
evidence.summary: Regular adherence to physical therapy exercises is associated with better outcomes in scoliosis management. Consistency matters more than intensity.

recommendation_templates.action: Try to complete your PT exercises daily. Even 10-15 minutes of consistent practice makes a difference.
Getting back on track with PT exercises is more important than making up missed days. Start fresh today.

evidence.title: When to Consult Healthcare Provider
evidence.summary: Consult a healthcare provider if experiencing new pain, significant posture changes, or if prescribed brace or exercises feel uncomfortable.

recommendation_templates.action: If you're experiencing new or increased back pain, it's a good idea to check in with your healthcare provider.
If your brace is causing discomfort, contact your orthotist. Adjustments can make a big difference.
